THE War Cabinet, after discussing the relative advantages of proceeding by legislation or by regulation, decided to approve the revised instructions to Tribunals circulated by the President ofthe Local Government Board, which provide, among other matters (a.) For the revision of Tribunal exemptions held by menup to the age of 31 not employed in certain specifiedoccupations.(b.) For the reduction from two months to a fortnight of theperiod within which an application for the renewal ofan exemption given on the ground of certified occupationmay be lodged.[1305-84 Amendment of 2. The War Cabinet decided that Military service acts. (a.) The draft report as to amendments to the Military service acts prepared by Lord Rhondda's Committee (WarCabinet, 64, Minute S) should be circulated to theDepartments concerned for their consideration.(b.) The same Committee, with the Minister of Munitions, theSecretary for Scotland, the Secretary of State for India,and Mr. David Shackleton, Permanent Secretary to theMinistry of Labour, should consider and report to theWar Cabinet on the general position as regardsthe supply of men for the Army, the policy to be adoptedwith regard to future legislation, and the modificationof existing methods of exemption (including the TradeCard scheme).(c ) A Sub-Committee, consisting of two representatives of theWar Office, one each of the Admiralty, Ministry ofMunitions, and Air Board, and Mr. Shackleton, should prepare and submit to the same Committee a schedule of the occupations from which men over certain agesshould not be withdrawn for military service, with anestimate of the numbers that might be renderedavailable if all. other forms of protection (apart fromTribunal exemptions) were abolished.(a7.) The War Office should furnish the War Cabinet with any information in their possession as to the position inFrance with regard to the exemption of munition workers.3. The War Cabinet decided that The Minister of Munitions should issue a notice to the effectthat the Government do not think it necessary on this occasion to interfere with the ordinary Easter holidays, buturge upon all workpeople the importance of returning towork promptly.4. The Prime Minister having read War Cabinet 13, Minute 8,Battalions. with regard to building up the Transport Workers' Battalion to atotal of 10,000 men-The Secretary of State for War undertook to use all possibleefforts to bring the numbers up to that total.(Initialled) D.
